tweets.text:
Paired bar charts suck at comparing values. The only reason they're used all the time is because they are easy to create.

But there are better alternatives that are just as easy.

Here's how to create 4 better alternatives with #rstats. https://t.co/P8YmZIgpcD

urls.title: How to Modify Variables the Right Way in R | R-bloggers
urls.description: Introduction In data analysis and data science, it‚Äôs common to work with large datasets that require some form of manipulation to be useful. In this small article, we‚Äôll explore how to create and modify columns in a dataframe using modern R tools from the tidyverse package. We can do that on several ways, so we are going from basic to advanced level. Let‚Äôs use the starwars dataset for that purpose: data("starwars") head(starwars, 4) # # A tibble: 4 √ó 8 # name height mass hair_color skin_color eye_color birth_year sex # # 1 Luke Skywalker 172 77 blond fair blue 19 male # 2 C-3PO 167 75 NA gold yellow 112 none # 3 R2-D2 96 32 NA white, blue red 33 none # 4 Darth Vader 202 136 none white yellow 41.9 male The most basic example is using mutate to create and modify variables. starwars %>% mutate( height = height * 2, new_numeric_column = row_number(), new_char_column = "This variable is new" ) %>% select(name, height, new_numeric_column, new_char_column) %>% head(4) # # A tibble: 4 √ó 4 # na

urls.title: New Data Viz & Data Art Projects and Updates
urls.description: Hi again! It‚Äôs ‚Äúonly‚Äù been about six months, so at least not another year as before ^_^ I don‚Äôt often get to work on maps, but a trip to Norway made me dive into OpenStreetMap and how to make a custom map (using JavaScript). And there are even two(!) new astronomy projects; the first a data art piece about exoplanets, the second a visual for Scientific American about our nearest stars „ÉªÔæü‚úß + some sneak peeks at what I‚Äôm working on now! Last year I traveled through Norway for 5 months, working on the bad
